It is incredible that the honourable member for Dawson should allow an upset for such a short time to concern him from 4.55 on one afternoon until 12.30 the following morning. He must have one of the most sensitive hearts and one of the most sensitive souls of any honourable member.

talk.start.para: -I want to supplement the remarks that have been made by saying only that 1 did ask, through the Government Whip, whether it would be possible for some variation to be made in the agenda for this afternoon. I did this, as the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Kevin Cairns) has just explained, so that I could be in the House during the debate on the Aged Persons Homes Bill. I might add that I am rather amazed that the honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson), knowing full well that he was to lead in the debate for the Opposition, should have made such extensive arrangements to beaway from the House on the day of the debate. The arrangements which were upset must have been of a duration beginning late this afternoon. It was very late in the afternoon when I made my request. I feel that the hours mentioned by the honourable member for Lilley fit in very much with the request that I made. If the honourable member for Dawson has been upset in his arrangements, I accept full responsibility for this and I apologise. Nevertheless I feel it is rather strange that in a programme which involves so much of the day his arrangements should have been upset to such an extent by a modification which, as I understand it, took no more than a quarter of an hour or half an hour to readjust.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 12.41 a.m. (Friday).

debate.para: The following answers to questions upon notice were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister represent ing the Minister for Supply, upon notice:

item.para: Is it a fact that the Government recently disposed of a large quantity of surplus Army rifles to an overseas buyer?
If so, what was the name and address of the buyer, and what was the purchase price?
Was the sale arranged by tender or otherwise?
Did other intending buyers submit offers for the purchase of the rifles; ifso, what are their names and addresses, and what was the amount of the offer in each case?
How many rifles were sold, and what was their description?
Were any undertakings sought and/or obtained from the purchaser as to the manner of disposal or destination of the rifles; if so, what are the details?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Supply has provided the following answers to the honourable member's questions:

item.para: In February of this year, the Department of Supply, on behalf of the Department of the Army, disposed of 20,000 surplus rifles to local buyers.

The Australian Council of State Rifle Associations, Victoria Barracks, Melbourne purchased 501 rifles for $3,207.50 and Sporting Arms Limited, Clovelly Park, South Australia purchased 19,499 rifles for $126,500.
Sales were arranged by tender. Licensed gunsmiths, dealers and the Australian Council of State Rifle Associations were invited to submit tenders.
There were seventeen other tenderers. It is not Commonwealth practice to divulge information regarding unsuccessful tenders.
As mentioned above, 20,000 rifles were sold. Their descriptions are as follows:

The tender schedule stated that tenderers intending to export any rifles to approved countries would require the written authority of the Comptroller-General of Customs and must comply with any conditions prescribed by the Comptroller-General. Sporting Arms Limited was permitted to export all rifles purchased by it, subject to the company's complying with the following conditions:
that all rifles were to be exported to Parker Hale Limited, Birmingham, United Kingdom;
that approval for export was to be obtained by the purchaser from the Comptroller-General of Customs; and
that Landing Certificaates were to be furnished in accordance with Section 126 of Customs Act 1901-1966.

The rifles were shipped by Sporting Arms Limited to the United Kingdom in three consignments and Landing Certificates have been furnished in respect of two consignments. The purchaser awaits receipt of the third certificate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice:

item.para: Has his Department any plans to move the Geelong rifle range to a site outside the urban area of Geelong?
On how many days in the last year was this range used for the training of Army personnel?
Has he received complaints from the Geelong Harbour Trust relating to the possible danger arising from the use of this range?
Does the use of this range necessitate the closure of the public of large areas of Corio Bay which is now widely used by the public for pleasure boating?
Will he have personal discussions with the Commissioners of the Geelong Harbour Trust with a view to the re-location of this range?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.para: There are no present plans to move the Geelong rifle range to a site outside the urban areas of Geelong.
The range was not used by the Army during the past twelve months.
No complaints have been received from the Geelong Harbour Trust in the last three years.
No.
No approach on this matter has been made by the Commissioners of the Geelong Harbour Trust, but should they do so, I would be happy to discuss any aspects of it.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Science, upon notice:

item.para: How many public relations officers or officers engaged in equivalent positions are employed by the Commonwealth Scientific and industrial Research Organisation?
In which divisions are they employed?
How many different publications are printed by the CSIRO?
What are the titles of these publications, and how often are they issued?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Education and Science has supplied the following information:

item.para: Commonwealth Scientific and Research Organisation has one officer in Canberra and one in Melbourne whose principle duties are public relations, that is liaison with the Press, radio and television and with the general public.

Both of these officers are on the staff of the Organisation's head office. In addition there are a number of other officers in CSIRO head office and in various division's whose duties are to provide information of a more technical nature to industry and to bodies such as State Departments of Agriculture. Although these officers are not primarily public relations officers, their work does have a substantial public relations content.

The CSIRO issues a wide variety of publications of a technical and semi-technical nature. The CSIRO also issues a list of these publications annually and a copy of this document has been forwarded to the honourable member.
Detailed information or titles of CSIRO publications and the frequency of their publication is contained in the list mentioned above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice:

quote.para: Will the Government consider undertaking, in co-operation with the States, a 10 year tick eradication programme with the object of trying to make Australia tick free by the end of that period?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The responsibility for tick control and eradication is primarily one for State Governments and the New South Wales and Queensland Governments have both been particularly active in undertaking control and eradication measures.

The Commonwealth is well aware of the magnitude of the problem and, over a long period has contributed generously to assist the States in this work. Since 1957-58 the Commonwealth has contributed in excess of $6m for tick control, quarantine and research in New South Wales alone. The agreement whereby the Commonwealth contributes half the estimated cost of interstate quarantine and research in New South Wales has recently been extended.

Since 1962, the Commonwealth has supported research into tick and tick fever on a$1 for $1 basis with industry, through the Meat Research Trust Account. Funds are made available to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Queensland De partment of Primary Industries and the University of Queensland. Research allocations from this source between 1962-63 and the current fiscal year have totaled $1,589,157;

The emergence of ticks resistant to acaricidcs has presented new problems. As a consequence, a Committee on Cattle Tick Resistance to Acaricides comprising Commonwealth and State experts has been set up by the Australian Agricultural Council. This Committee has considered the question of eradicating the tick from northern areas of Australia but agreed that, as long as there was a lack of adequate fencing facilities on the more extensively managed properties inthese areas coupled with feralanimal populations, and reliance had to be placed mainly upon chemical means of control, a programme to achieve eradication would not be effective. Despite repeated attempts since 1932 in New South Wales, programmes aimed at eradication have not succeeded.

It would appear that if a means of eradicating the cattle tick is to be found, it will most probably arise as a result of comprehensive and sustained research. Such research activities will continue to receive support.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice:

item.para: Did publication of the 'Handbook of Australian Fishes' in his Department's monthly Fisheries Newsletter cease in February 1962?
What reasons other than or in addition to those in his answer to me on 15th April 1959 (Hansard, page 1266) are responsible for this second and continuing interruption?
Does his Department propose to resume publication; if so, in what form and on what date?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: Yes, publication of the 'Handbook of Australian Fishes' in Fisheries Newsletter in serial form, which began in July 1956 was, as I advised the Leader of the Opposition, suspended temporarily in January 1959 because of the inability of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Fisheries and Oceanography to furnish the necessary material concurrently with other work being undertaken by that Division. Publication was resumed in March 1960 but had to be suspended again in December 1961 when the CSIRO Division of Fisheries and Oceanography was unable to provide the material, because of other higher priority commitments.

My Department had hoped that the publication of this valuable reference work would have been resumed but the CSIROofficer responsible for the work, Mr I. S. R. Munro, has continued to be engaged in other important work including technical control of the prawn survey in the Gulf of Carpentaria which has stimulated the development of important prawn fisheries in that area.
It is hoped to complete the work, but, at present, I am unable to give any definite date as to when it will be resumed.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice:

question.para: Has any communication passed between the Commonwealth and any State Government, since his answer to me on 22nd September 1966 (Hansard, page 1248), concerning the ratification of International Labour Organisation Convention No. 107 cited as the Indigenous and Tribal Populations Convention 1957?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Since my answer to the honourable member's question on 22nd September 1966, there has been continuing consideration of the relevant law and practice affecting the question of ratification of this Convention. Further progress has been made and South Australia has now passed the Aboriginal Lands Trust Act.

As I have previously assured the honourable gentleman, the Convention is being kept under examination by the Commonwealth and the States with a view to the implementation of its provisions where possible.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, upon notice:

item.para: Is it a fact that the housing position in Western Australia is worsening to the extent of approximately 4,000 a year?
Are there at present over 12,000 applicants awaiting State Housing Commission houses.
What was the waiting period to purchase a house at (a) 30th June 1965 and (b) 30th June 1967?
Is it a fact that some applicants, classed as emergent by the Commission, have to wait as long as 3 months before getting a house?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Housing has provided the following answers to the honourable member's questions:

item.para: No.
Yes.

The Western Australian Housing Commission has provided the following information. At 30th June 1965, applications to purchase a Commission home received in the Perth area in June 1964 and in Fremantle in April 1964 were receiving attention. At 30th June 1967 applications to purchase a Commission home in Perth area received in January 1965, applications for Fremantle received in May 1965 and for Midland in July 1965, were receiving attention.

Yes, but with the State Housing Commission's qualification that these would be special cases requiring particular locations (such as asthmatics), and persons requiring particular types of accommodation (such as dwellings without steps for the elderly or with ramps for paraplegics). Under normal circumstances 'emergents' are satisfied from immediately to 6 weeks depending on the circumstances of each case.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Navy, upon notice:

item.para: In view of his answer to me on 19th September (Hansard, page 1091) to the effect that at the time he spoke in the 'Voyager' debate on 16th May he was aware of the existence of Lieutenant-Commander Griffith's statement and of its general effect but that he did not in fact see it until afterwards, will he say when and by whom he was acquainted with the general effect of the statement?
When and by whom was he shown the statement?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.para: The statement referred to was taken by the Attorney-General's Department on 15th May, 1967, at its own instigation. The Secretary of my Department was informed by an officer of the Attorney-General's Department on the evening of 15th May that a statement bad been taken, and of its general effect. This information was conveyed to me by the Secretary of my Department that evening.
Shortly after 16th May I read a copy of the statement on the Departmental file.
